results.title: Everybody's handicapped
results.creator_credit: Ernest Reid, Graphic Associates and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: A National Employment Service placement officer learns that in the man who is physically disabled he has as good a product to sell as in the one without a disability - that the properly placed so-called disabled worker is no more disabled vocationally than the ordinary worker. In support, the film shows many instances of exceptional job performance by disabled workers, illustrating that, from the employer’s point of view, physical limitations are amply compensated for by greater efficiency, less absenteeism and a lower accident rate.

results.title: Everybody's Gone to the Rapture
results.brief_description: Rapture is inspired by the fiction of John Wyndham, J. G. Ballard, John Christopher and other authors who deal with ordinary people in extraordinary circumstances. But it’s also about the end of the world.

constellations_other.name: The world's end
constellations_other.description: For people of colour oppressed by systemic racism, genre stories about the end of the world and cosmological monsters can be used to re-examine race and the injustices faced in real life.

results.description:
For the last twelve months, we’ve had our heads down working hard on Everybody’s Gone to the Rapture and it’s really exciting to be able to share some more information with you as well as a new trailer.

If you already know The Chinese Room, you’ll know that we make story-driven games. Creating a rich, deep world with strong drama and exceptional production values is key to what we’re all about. Rapture is set in a remote valley in June 1984 and is a story about people and how they live with each other. But it’s also about the end of the world.

Rapture is inspired by the fiction of John Wyndham, J. G. Ballard, John Christopher and other authors who deal with ordinary people in extraordinary circumstances. There’s a very particular English feel that we wanted to capture in the game, a combination of the epic and the intimate. Rapture also came from our obsession with post-apocalyptic gaming, and the simple idea that whilst we normally play as the hero, in reality, most of us would be the piles of ash and bone littering the game world. That’s an interesting place to start telling a story.

Our approach is to create a game that you can utterly immerse yourself in. Yaughton Valley, where Rapture takes place, is a living, breathing world. The world of Rapture is not just a backdrop; it’s a character in its own right. It’s great working with PS4 as its processing power makes a game like this possible for a team our size.

The game is all about discovery. It’s open-world so you have the freedom to explore wherever you like, visiting areas in an order you define, and the story is written to allow this whilst making sure every player has a strong dramatic experience. It’s a type of storytelling that is completely unique to games. The choices you make as a player have a direct impact on how you understand the story – the more you explore and interact, the deeper you are drawn into Rapture’s world.

results.title: Everybody's fine = Stanno tutti bene
results.creator_credit: Giuseppe Tornatore, Angelo Rizzoli, Sovereign Pictures, TF1 Films productions, Les Films Ariane and ERRE
results.brief_description: Matteo Scuri (Marcello Mastroianni) is a gentle warm-hearted widower and the proudest father of all in Italy. With his five children all successes in their own right, Matteo can’t help but boast about them to everyone he meets - including strangers! For years his children, scattered throughout Italy, have paid an annual visit on his birthday. But this year, they are unable to make it. Disappointed and feeling a little lost, Matteo decides to pay his children a surprise visit, and reunite them all for another family celebration. As he crosses a noisy and crazy country, the trip becomes a revelation as he discovers the real lives of the children he thought he knew. A chronicle of one man’s haunting journey of discovery, this film touches all emotions - a truly captivating cinematic experience from director Giuseppe Tornatore. English subtitles.

results.title: Everybody's business: management in action (NP)
results.creator_credit: Mark Davis, Open Learning Agency of Australia, Monash University and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: Today the workplace is changing. Quantum changes in the world economy, in technology and in society itself have brought about a revolution in the nature of work. Increasing use of self-management strategies have led to a far greater sharing of management functions through the whole workforce. The classic functions of management - planning, organising, leading, and controlling are becoming everybody’s business, hence the title of this series. Throughout the series, reporter Cheryl Hall explores the new approaches to management in all sectors of the workforce. Kerry O’Brien speaks to experts on the key issues of management today.

results.title: Every valley
results.creator_credit: Michael Clarke, Edgar H. Anstey and British Transport Films
results.brief_description: An impression, from daybreak to midnight, of the life of the industrial valleys of South Wales and of the growing part played in that life by bus and railway. The free verse spoken by Donald Houston acts as a link between various arias, choruses and orchestral interludes from Handel’s “Messiah” that utter their own comment, lyrical, ironic or humorous, upon the pictures of Welsh life and landscape they accompany.

results.title: Every square inch
results.brief_description: Every square inch of Canada, second largest country in the world, has been put on maps, and much of it is being mapped again, even more thoroughly. How such a vast territory is committed to paper is seen in this film, stage by stage: aerial photography; ground surveying with sophisticated instruments and at headquarters, the exacting work of translating, plotting, and printing.

results.title: Every second counts
results.brief_description: Every second counts when a bushfire rages. Fire towers, well trained crews and equipment stands by the roadside are all part of the fire fighting organisation maintained by the SEC for the protection of the Kiewa hydro-electric power scheme. Prevention methods include the construction of fire trails and the planting of green summer grasses.
